questions.question_text:
You are designing a Microsoft Teams application. The application will enable content authors to start conversations about news coming from a third-party application.
Which development technique should you use?

comments.content: Agreed. I was skeptical at first but next question answer has info that proves it out.
For more information also take a look at the next question.

discussion.content: The application will enable content authors "to start conversations", not "receiving items". It is about de "conversation" functionality you want to offer in your app. With "Deep Links" you can get to these items. So, for me answer D is correct.
Wouldn't the answer to this be A - as we are receiving items from an external news source? Deep Links simply provide links to content inside Teams

comments.content: Deep links don't simply provide links to content inside Teams, you can create chats, schedule meetings, create tasks, etc...

discussion.content:
B Outgoing webhooks - allow external applications to send messages to a specified Teams channel. This means that when new content is published in your third-party application, users can use an outgoing webhook to send a message to the Teams channel, which will start a conversation about the news.
Incoming webhooks, on the other hand, are used to receive messages from Teams into application. Activity feeds and deep links are not directly related to this case.

Selected Answer: A
I get the arguments for D about "starting a conversation", but I'd still go for A. There is just too much unnecessary info in the question if the answer was D:
 - Why exactly is there a third-party app sending messages mentioned if it is not relevant at all?
 - Deep links do not enable starting a conversation. This feature is already enabled by the standard Teams functionality. Deep links can only make it more convenient.

questions.question_text:
You are developing a Microsoft Teams app in a tenant.
You pilot the app to only 10 users in the tenant and test the app.
You need to deploy the app to all the users in the tenant.
What should you do?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
I think the correct answer should be B according to docs:
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/MicrosoftTeams/teams-app-permission-policies
Global (Org-wide default) policy exists by default and applies to all users. Any changes made to this policy impact all users as this policy is applied to all users by default.

An admin-created policy applies only to the users that it is applied to. Create a new policy to allow apps for specific users or group of users.

choices.C: Enable sideloading in a custom app setup policy.
choices.B: Add the app to the global (Org-wide default) policy.

discussion.content:
the provided awnser is false.
see the link in the solution: it clearly says:
composeExtensions
and then 
Commands

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT -
You have a Microsoft Teams app that contains a conversational bot. The bot uses task modules to reply to users. When the bot receives a new message, the following code is executed before a response is sent back to the user to decide whether the bot should continue the conversation.
//IMG//

Use the drop-down menus to select the answer choice that completes each statement based on the information presented in the graphic.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Hot Area:
//IMG//

discussion.content: I think the second box should be "stop interacting with the bot"

comments.content: case "final" is break. the suggested answer does not make sense.

discussion.content:
Answer A: Continue interacting. https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/javascript/api/botbuilder/session?view=botbuilder-ts-3.0 lookup "send"

Answer B: Stop interacting: It's literally a break statement
Does anyone know if the provided answer is valid?
